prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong here. So the situation is that the husband set up his office in the bedroom, even though the wife suggested the basement. Now, because he's on conference calls, the wife has to keep the kids from disturbing him, which limits her ability to do her own work, chores, and even basic things like showering or napping.

First, I need to consider both sides. The husband chose the bedroom over the basement for the view. But the basement is quieter, which is logical for someone who works from home. The wife is taking on most of the house chores and dealing with the kids. By having the office in the bedroom, it's causing her a lot of inconvenience. 

The key points here are about mutual respect and consideration. The husband is prioritizing his comfort (view) over creating a functional workspace that minimizes disruption. The wife is trying to balance her work and household responsibilities, which are being hindered by his choice. 

Also, the wife made a clear suggestion (basement) that he ignored. He's expecting her to ensure silence, which is not feasible if she's managing kids and chores. The fact that he's in the bedroom complicates things because that's a shared space, so her normal activities are affected. 

From a fairness standpoint, the husband's decision is causing more problems. The wife is not at fault for refusing to be quiet when her needs are being neglected. The problem stems from the husband not considering the practicality of his workspace choice. So the author (wife) isn't in the wrong here. Answer B.
